question_stem: From a collection of nine paintings, four are to be selected to hang side-by-side on a gallery wall in positions 1, 2, 3 and 4. In how many ways can this be done?
A group of 60 freshmen are to be randomly assigned into two classes of 30 students each, one on the first floor and one on the second floor. In how many ways can this be done?

Suppose we have with us a biased coin. In other words, the probability of heads is p, where p > 0.5. We flip the coin twice, and define the following events: A1 : we observe head followed by a tail. A2 : we observe a tail followed by a head. What is P(A1 | A1 U A2)?
concept_tags.question_stem: Suppose we have with us a biased coin. In other words, the probability of heads is p, where p >0.5. We flip the coin twice, and define the following events: A1: we observe head followed by a tail A2: we observe a tail followed by a head. What is P(A1 | A1 U A2)?
If 8 identical blackboards are to be divided among 4 schools, how many divisions are possible?
If 8 distinct blackboards are to be divided equally among 4 schools, how many possible assignments are there?
Which of the following is not a cumulative distribution function?
Which of the following is not a cumulative distribution function? [Missing formula options for comparison]

Two players, A and B, alternately and independently flip a coin and the first player to obtain a head wins. Assume player A flips first. Define Ei to be the event that head appears first on the i-th toss. What is P(A wins)?

A fair coin is tossed independently 10 times. Define the following events: Ak : the k-th toss is heads. S: the total number of heads observed in the 10 tosses is even. (Note that 0 is an even number). What is P(S | A1 A2 A3 ... A10)?

A fair coin is tossed independently 10 times. Define the following events: Ak: the k-th toss is heads S10: the total number of heads observed in the 10 tosses is even. (Note that 0 is an even number). What is P(S10 | A1 A2 A3 ... A10)?

Two players, A and B, alternately and independently flip a coin and the first player to obtain a head wins. Assume player A flips first. Define Ei to be the event that head appears first on the i-th toss. Which of the following statements is true about the sequence of events Ei?

Two players, A and B, alternately and independently flip a coin and the first player to obtain a head wins. Assume player A flips first. Define Ei to be the event that head appears first on the i-th toss. Which of the following statements is true about the sequence of events Ei?
Suppose that p(x) and q(x) are two distinct pmfs. Then for any b such that 0 < b < 1, r(x) = bp(x) + (1-b)q(x) is also a pmf.
Suppose that p(x) and q(x) are two distinct pmfs. Then for any b such that 0 <b <1, r(x) = bp(x) + (1-b)q(x) is also a pmf.

Two fair six-sided dice are rolled. Let X be the product of the two dice. What is P(X >= 33)?

Consider the following pmf [Missing formula/expression], for i = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ...}. Find P(X = 1 | {X=1} U {X=2})
A deck of playing cards has 52 cards. Four of these cards are Aces. Suppose that a well-shuffled deck of cards is dealt out. What is the probability that the 14th card dealt out is an Ace?

Let X be a random variable denoting the number of children in a family. X has support {1,2,3,4}, and pmf given by: p(1)=0.1, p(2)=0.25, p(3)=0.35, p(4)=0.3. A child from this family is chosen at random (i.e. all children within a family are equally likely to be selected). Let E be the event that the eldest child is chosen. Find P(X=1 | E).

Let X be a random variable denoting the number of children in a family. X has support {1,2,3,4}, and pmf given by p(1) p(2) p(3) p(4) 0.1 0.25 0.35 0.3 A child from this family is chosen at random (i.e. all children within a family are equally likely to be selected). Let E be the event that the eldest child is chosen. Find P(X=1 | E).

An urn has n white and m black balls. Balls are randomly withdrawn without replacement, one at a time, until a total of k white balls have been withdrawn, where k <= n. The random variable X is the total number of balls that have been withdrawn. Which of the following events is equivalent to {X = r}, where r is an integer in the support of X?

Let E, F and G be three events from a sample space. Match the following descriptions to the events regarding E, F and G below. There is only one matching description for each event. Descriptions: 1. E occurs. 2. At least two of the events occur. 3. Exactly two events occur. 4. The empty set occurs. 5. None of the three events occur. 6. Only E occurs. Match the events: (E U F U G)^c, (E intersect F) U (E intersect G) U (F intersect G).

Let E, F and G be three events from a sample space. Match the following descriptions to the events regarding E, F and G below. There is only one matching description for each event. 1. E occurs. 2. At least two of the events occur. 3. Exactly two events occur. 4. The empty set occurs. 5. None of the three events occur. 6. Only E occurs. _____________ 1 (E U F U G)^c _____________ 2 (E & F) U (E & G) U (F & G)

Let E, F and G be three events from a sample space. Match the following descriptions to the events regarding E,F and G below. There is only one matching description for each event. Descriptions: 1. E occurs. 2. At least two of the events occur. 3. Exactly two events occur. 4. Exactly one of the events occurs. 5. Only E occurs. 6. At least one of the events occurs. Match the events: E U F U G, E intersect F^c intersect G^c.

Let E, F and G be three events from a sample space. Match the following descriptions to the events regarding E,F and G below. There is only one matching description for each event. 1. E occurs. 2. At least two of the events occur. 3. Exactly two events occur. 4. Exactly one of the events occurs. 5. Only E occurs. 6. At least one of the events occurs. _____________ 1 E U F U G _____________ 2 E & F^c & G^c

A fair coin is tossed independently n times, where n >= 2. Define the following events: Ak : the k-th toss is heads. Sn : the total number of heads observed in the n tosses is even. (Note that 0 is an even number). Is the collection of events A1, A2, A3, ... An, Sn independent? Hint: Consider P(Sn | A1 A2 A3 ... An).

A fair coin is tossed independently n times, where n >= 2. Define the following events: Ak: the k-th toss is heads Sn: the total number of heads observed in the n tosses is even. (Note that 0 is an even number). Is the collection of events A1, A2, A3, ..., An, Sn independent? Hint: Consider P(Sn | A1 A2 A3 ... An)
Suppose that A and B are independent events such that the probability that neither occurs is a, and the probability that B occurs is b. Find P(A).
A fair coin is tossed independently n times, where n >= 2. Define the following events: Ak : the k-th toss is heads. What is P(A1 A2 A3 A4 ... An)?
A fair coin is tossed independently n times, where n >= 2. Define the following events: Ak: the k-th toss is heads. What is P(A1 A2 A3 A4 ... An)?
Suppose that E1, E2, ... En are independent events. Which of the following statements is true for any such collection of events? [Statement/equation for options A, B, C missing in text].
Suppose that E1, E2, ..., En are independent events. Which of the following statements is true for any such collection of events? [Missing statements for comparison]

Independent trials are performed indefinitely, where each trial consists of rolling a pair of fair six-sided dice, and then summing the values on the dice at each trial. Thus, if we observe (1,2), (3,4) and (6,6) in the first three trials, then the outcomes of the first three trials are recorded as 3, 7 and then 12. We define En to be the event that no 5 or 7 appears on the first n-1 trials and a 5 appears on the n-th trial. What does the event (union of En from n=1 to infinity) correspond to?

Independent trials are performed indefintely, where each trial consists of rolling a pair of fair six-sided dice, and then summing the values on the dice at each trial. Thus, if we observe (1,2), (3,4) and (6,6) in the first three trials, then the outcomes of the first three trials are recorded as 3, 7 and then 12. We define En to be the event that no 5 or 7 appears on the first n-1 trials and a 5 appears on the n-th trial. What does the event correspond to?

Suppose that X is a discrete random variable with support on the set {1,2,3,4}. We define the sequence of events En to be [Missing definition of En]. What is [Missing expression to evaluate]?
Suppose that A and B are mutually exclusive, and P(A) > 0 and P(B) > 0. Which of the following statements is false?
Suppose that A and B are mutually exclusive, and P(A) >0 and P(B) >0. Which of the following statements is false?
Suppose that A and B are events with positive probability. Determine if the following statement is true or false: If A and B are not mutually exclusive, then they are independent.
Suppose that A and B form a partition of the sample space, and P(A) > 0 and P(B) > 0. Which of the following statements is false?
Suppose that A and B form a partition of the sample space, and P(A) >0 and P(B) >0. Which of the following statements is false?

A mobile phone manufacturing company has two factories X and Y. Factories X and Y produce 30% and 70% of all mobile phones respectively. 9% of the phones produced by factory X are defective, and 1% of the phones produced by factory Y are defective. If a phone bought from the company is found to be defective, what is the probability that it was produced by factory X?
Which of the following is not a probability mass function? [PMF functions for options A, B, C missing in text].
Which of the following is not a probability mass function? [Missing pmf options for comparison]
Consider the following pmf, for i in {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ...}. [PMF formula missing in text]. Evaluate the cdf at i=2.
Consider the following pmf [Missing formula/expression], for i = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ...}. Evaluate the cdf at i=2.
A and B are mutually exclusive events. Further, P(A) = 0.3 and P(B) = 0.2. What is the probability that both events occur?
How many ways can we arrange the letters in the word 'VISITING' such that no two 'I's are adjacent? Hint: Experiment 1: Permute the non-I letters. Experiment 2: Choose where to put the I's.
How many ways can we arrange the letters in the word 'VISITING'?

Independent trials are performed indefinitely, where each trial consists of rolling a pair of fair six-sided dice, and then summing the values on the dice at each trial. Thus, if we observe (1,2), (3,4) and (6,6) in the first three trials, then the outcomes of the first three trials are recorded as 3, 7 and then 12. We define En to be the event that no 5 or 7 appears on the first n-1 trials and a 5 appears on the n-th trial. Is En an increasing or decreasing sequence?

Independent trials are performed indefintely, where each trial consists of rolling a pair of fair six-sided dice, and then summing the values on the dice at each trial. Thus, if we observe (1,2), (3,4) and (6,6) in the first three trials, then the outcomes of the first three trials are recorded as 3, 7 and then 12. We define En to be the event that no 5 or 7 appears on the first n-1 trials and a 5 appears on the n-th trial. Is En an increasing or decreasing sequence?
Suppose that A, B and C are events from a sample space. Which of the following statements is not true for all possible choices of A, B and C? [Statements for options A, B, C missing in text].
Suppose that A, B and C are events from a sample space. Which of the following statements is not true for all possible choices of A, B and C? [Missing statements for comparison]
A closet contains 10 pairs of shoes. If 8 shoes are randomly selected, what is the probability that there will be no complete pair? [Options A, B, C containing formulas/values missing in text].
A closet contains 10 pairs of shoes. If 8 shoes are randomly selected, what is the probability that there will be no complete pair? [Missing formula options for calculation]
There are n socks in a drawer, 3 of which are red. What is the value of n if, when 2 of the socks are chosen randomly, the probability that they are both red is 1/2?

Suppose that the random variable X has support {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, .... }. For i in this set, the pmf is given by P(X = i) = 1/i - 1/(i+1). If we let Y = 2 - X, what is the pmf of Y evaluated at -5? In other words, what is P(Y = -5)?

Suppose that the random variable X has support {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, .... }. For i in this set, the pmf is given by P(X = i) = 1/i - 1/(i+1) If we let Y = 2 - X, what is the pmf of Y evaluated at -5? In other words, what is P(Y = -5)?
Suppose that the random variable X has support {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, .... }. For i in this set, the pmf is given by P(X = i) = 1/i - 1/(i+1). If we let Y = 1 if X <= 2 and 0 otherwise, what is P(Y = 0)?
Suppose that the random variable X has support {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, .... }. For i in this set, the pmf is given by P(X = i) = 1/i - 1/(i+1) If we let Y = 1 if X <= 2 and 0 otherwise, what is P(Y = 0)?

There are 4 TV repairmen and 8 TV repair jobs. If it is possible for a single repairman to do multiple jobs, how many possible assignments of repairmen to jobs are there? [Options A, B, C containing formulas/values missing in text].

There are 4 TV repairmen and 8 TV repair jobs. If it is possible for a single repairman to do multiple jobs, how many possible assignments of repairmen to jobs are there? [Missing formula options for calculation]
If P(A) = 1/4 and P(B) = 1/3, then [equation/inequality missing in text]. True/False.
If P(A) = 1/4 and P(B) = 1/3, then [Missing inequality/equation].
If P(A)=1/3 and P(B^c)=1/4 then it is still possible for A and B to be disjoint.
If P(A)=1/3 and P(B^c)=1/4 then it is still possible for A and B to be disjoint.

A company has two factories X and Y. Factories X and Y produce 40% and 60% of all watches respectively. 2% of the watches produced by factory X are defective, and 3% of the watches produced by factory Y are defective. If a watch bought from the company is found to be defective, what is the probability that it was produced by factory Y?

An urn has n white and m black balls. Balls are randomly withdrawn without replacement, one at a time, until a total of k white balls have been withdrawn, where k <= n. The random variable X is the total number of balls that have been withdrawn. What is the support of X?

Let X be a random variable denoting the number of children in a family. X has support {1,2,3,4}, and pmf given by: p(1)=0.3, p(2)=0.25, p(3)=0.35, p(4)=0.1. A child from this family is chosen at random (i.e. all children are equally likely to be selected). Let E be the event that the youngest child is chosen. Find P(E).

Let X be a random variable denoting the number of children in a family. X has support {1,2,3,4}, and pmf given by p(1) p(2) p(3) p(4) 0.3 0.25 0.35 0.1 A child from this family is chosen at random (i.e. all children are equally likely to be selected). Let E be the event that the youngest child is chosen. Find P(E).
